contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox CFL player |Color=#c7cad0 |fontcolor=#000080 |name=Kelvin Anderson |image= |caption= |birth_date={{birth date and age|1972|2|4}} |birth_place=[[South Bend, Indiana]] |death_date= |death_place= |status=Retired |import=yes |position1=Running back |College=[[Southeast Missouri State]] |DraftedYear= |DraftedRound= |Career Highlights=Y |CFLAllStar=[[1998 CFL season#1998 CFL All-Stars|1998]], [[1999 CFL season#1999 CFL All-Stars|1999]], [[2001 CFL season#2001 CFL All-Stars|2001]] |Awards=[[1996 CFL season|1996]] [[CFL's Most Outstanding Rookie Award|CFL Rookie of the Year]]<br>[[1998 CFL season|1998]] [[Jeff Nicklin Memorial Trophy]]<br>[[2001 CFL season|2001]] [[Jeff Nicklin Memorial Trophy]] |Honors= |ProBowls= |playing_years={{CFL Year|1996}}-{{CFL Year|2002}}<br>2001<br>{{CFL Year|2003}} |playing_teams=[[Calgary Stampeders]]<br>[[San Francisco Demons]] - [[XFL]]<br>[[BC Lions]] |DatabaseFootball= |PFR= |CFHOF= |CFHOFYear= |CollegeHOF=}} '''Kelvin Anderson''' (born February 4, 1972) is a retired professional [[gridiron football]] player. As a [[running back]], he rushed for over 1,000 yards in eight consecutive seasons in the [[Canadian Football League]], a league record. He won the CFL's [[Grey Cup]] championship twice, as a member of the [[Calgary Stampeders]], in [[1998 Grey Cup|1998]] and [[2001 Grey Cup|2001]]. Born February 4, 1972, in [[South Bend, Indiana]], Anderson played football at New Madrid County Central High School, where he earned the nickname "Earthquake". He played college football at [[Southeast Missouri State]]. Anderson's eight consecutive 1,000 yard seasons began in [[1996 CFL season|1996]] with the [[Calgary Stampeders]]. In 2000 he played in 15 games for Calgary, and ran for 1,048 yards and scored six touchdowns. He caught 34 passes for 283 yards and two touchdowns, and captured the [[Eddie James Memorial Trophy]] as the Western Divisionâ€™s top rusher. In [[2001 CFL season|2001]] he was named a Western All-Star for the fifth consecutive season, and was named a CFL All-Star for the third time in his career, and ran for a career-high 1,383 yards and six touchdowns. Anderson also caught 48 passes for 433 yards and nine touchdowns. Anderson also played in the only [[XFL]] season in 2001 for the [[San Francisco Demons]], leading the team in rushing with 228 yards. Anderson had played all of his CFL career with the Calgary Stampeders when he was released by them prior to the [[2003 CFL season|2003 season]] in favor of [[Lawrence Phillips]]. Anderson signed with the [[BC Lions]], following head coach and general manager [[Wally Buono]] who had also been let go by Calgary. With the Lions in 2003, he rushed for over 1,000 yards for the eighth consecutive season, setting a league record. He retired just prior the [[2004 CFL season]].
